criteria: Justification with Visual Models or Equations
descriptions: Student is unable to decompose the given fraction or shows no understanding of fraction decomposition.
Student attempts to decompose the fraction but makes significant errors in understanding or calculation.
Student decomposes the fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator, but only in one way and with minor errors.
Student decomposes the fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in more than one way, but lacks justification or has some inaccuracies.
Student accurately decomposes the fraction into a sum of fractions with the same denominator in multiple ways, providing a correct justification (e.g., visual model or equation).

Student demonstrates a comprehensive understanding of fraction decomposition by decomposing the fraction in multiple ways, providing clear and accurate justifications, and can apply this understanding to more complex fractions or scenarios.
No attempt to justify the decomposition is made, or the justification is completely irrelevant.
An attempt to justify the decomposition is made, but it is unclear, incorrect, or incomplete.
The justification is present but contains inaccuracies or lacks clarity. The connection between the decomposition and justification is weak.
The justification is adequate and supports the decomposition, but could be more clear or detailed. A visual model or equation is used, but not effectively.
The justification is clear, accurate, and effectively supports the decomposition. A visual model or equation is used appropriately to explain the decomposition.
The justification is thorough, insightful, and demonstrates a deep understanding of fraction decomposition. The visual model or equation is used creatively and effectively to enhance understanding.
